a dark ground. By increasing the power 
of the discharge these lines become more 
brilliant, but the brilliancy does not 
increase in the same ratio for them all. New 
bright lines appear, which formerly, on account of their extreme faintness, were

By increasing the heat of the ignited Nitro 
gen to the last extremity, the lines, es 
pecially the brighter ones gradually ex 
pend, approaching thus to a continuous 
spectrum.
34. Those spectra which are composed of larger 
bands, showing various appearances,
<u>according to their being differently sha 
dowed by <s>fine<\s> subtle dark lines<\u>, we generally 
call spectra of the first order. In the 
same spectrum the character of bands is,
to a certain extent the same, the breadth 
of the bands varies in a more or less regu 
lar way. On the contrary, those spectra 
in which brilliant coloured lines rise from 
a more or less dark ground, we call <u>spec 
tra of the second order<\u>.
Ignited Nitrogen therefore exhibits, if 
its temperature increase, successively 
two spectra of the first and one of 
the second order.
